18.text:
>> The main facts and figures on this topic
-- an important topic for us, I think -- are

26.text:
all in the paper, and I am not going to run
through the paper in order, as it were. I

31.text:
want to focus on the implications of it for
us as we go forward. It links very much back

35.text:
to the earlier discussion about how we make
all this practical and concrete and get on

40.text:
with doing it.
There is of course the welcome confirmation

45.text:
that another year of headline preservation
of the health spend, in real terms, is there,

52.text:
unlike most of the rest of the public sector,
and there are some very graphic charts that

57.text:
we all saw about that. The big news in this,
as David mentioned earlier, is the creation

62.text:
of the integration transformation fund of
nearly £4 billion that is being put together.

75.text:
There is £1.7 billion of that which is already
in the system, where health is in one form

81.text:
or another supporting the social care system
in its various activities. However, there

87.text:
is an additional £2.1 billion -- a little
bit next year and then a lot of '15/'16 -- which

93.text:
needs to be found from existing sources through
savings to make that fund a reality. And it

98.text:
is that which will concentrate our minds,
I think, as we go forward.

104.text:
We talked about clarity in a large part of
the rest of the agenda. The details of exactly

111.text:
how this fund is going to work, what the basis
of it is going to be, which section it is

115.text:
all going to be organised under is still very
much being worked through, in detail, between

119.text:
the two departments concerned: NHS England
and the Local Government Association. Contrary

128.text:
to the simplistic assumption in this paper,
which was right at the time we wrote it but

132.text:
seems now to be not quite as clear, it is
not a foregone conclusion that the money will

137.text:
simply go straight across and be held by the
local authority. It is much more open than

143.text:
that. The one clear thing is that it will
be pooled money which needs to be managed

146.text:
within the local health economy by the CCGs,
the local authorities concerned and, indeed,

153.text:
the Health and Wellbeing Board as the unit
that brings all that together.

158.text:
There is now, I think, a shared determination
that the routing of the funding should be

162.text:
through the CCGs. That is not an administrative
matter, that is quite an important part of

167.text:
making sure the ownership of this and the
ability to influence the way in which the

171.text:
money is spent and the outcomes reflects the
locus of the CCG as the local representation

183.text:
of clinical leadership in the health service.
That is important. I would say, though, that

188.text:
until we get complete crystal clarity on how
the mechanism of this is going to go, the

193.text:
precise answer to how the accountabilities
get exercised in all of this, who exactly

198.text:
is responsible for what, what the line of
sight is through the system will remain to

203.text:
be clarified.
Whatever the legal niceties, the one thing

208.text:
we do know is that there are two salient questions
that we need to address with some urgency.

214.text:
The first of those is: what are we going to
do with a fund of £3.8 billion which will

219.text:
really make a difference in local health economies?
How are we going to get this integration concept

224.text:
moving for the maximum benefit for patients
and, dare I say it, also for the maximum efficiency

229.text:
for the taxpayer; both of those go hand in
hand. It is a really serious piece of work

234.text:
to make concrete what we have been thinking
and talking about for many months, if not

241.text:
years.
Some of that thinking is represented in the

243.text:
conditions that you can see listed in the
document in front of you, which are things

248.text:
that, together, the CCGs and the local authorities
will have to work their way through. However,

253.text:
these will be a deeply local set of approaches
to it that reflect the local circumstances.

259.text:
There is not a one-size-fits-all approach.
That is one of the questions that needs to

262.text:
be answered, and it is the one frankly that
most people are perhaps most focused on at

266.text:
the moment.
Equally important, if not more important,

269.text:
though, is that you cannot spend money that
you do not have. There is a rather thornier

273.text:
question that we need to address, which is,
how do we generate savings of £2 billion

278.text:
on top of all the savings we already have
to generate on an annual basis to keep going.

283.text:
How do we generate that in a way which sustains
healthcare and does not cause unintended consequences

290.text:
of a significant nature. So you will be aware
of the kind of efficiency level in the system

294.text:
at the moment, the ask on the system is about
4% to 5% if you add together the provider

299.text:
and the commissioner ask at the moment. That
trips up to at least 6% to 7% when you put

304.text:
an additional ask of £2 billion into the
system and, as David has already said, that

308.text:
is a non-trivial ask; it is not just a small
adjustment to the percentage savings that

312.text:
need to be done. That takes us into a whole
different category of the stretch that is

317.text:
required.
The most obvious conclusion is that you cannot

329.text:
achieve that through business as usual; you
cannot do that by salami-slicing; you cannot

333.text:
do that through incremental gains of one sort
or another. If you want to invest cash, you

340.text:
have to generate it and that means effectively
disinvesting in other activities of one sort

345.text:
or another. In the discussion that we have,
we cannot pretend we can just generate the

350.text:
money without making changes. So we are going
to have to find some clear

359.text:
strategies for shifting activities, shifting
resource to create that capacity. Equally

365.text:
important, having shifted the activity, we
have to find a way of taking out the cost

368.text:
from where it is currently being incurred,
and there are complexities in that that we

372.text:
are all familiar with.
The second thing that is obvious is that if

375.text:
we start planning for that when we get to
'15/'16, it will be too late to do that because

379.text:
you cannot do that sort of change on a short-term
basis. We have to start planning now if we

385.text:
are going to free that up for '15/'16.
Of course, there is a strong link to the Call

389.text:
to Action that we talked about earlier. This
is one of the means by which all of that gets

393.text:
made concrete. We talked about the Call to
Action as being a five- to ten-year challenge,

398.text:
possibly longer than that, in its vision.
This brings it very much to a 90-week challenge,

403.text:
and I think we just have to square up to that
quite quickly and work out how we are going

406.text:
to make a reality of that.
What are we going to do about it? To make

411.text:
sure that every health economy is well prepared
for that challenge, we are about to launch

415.text:
a process of accelerated planning, where CCG
teams, area teams and other local partners

421.text:
in health and social care can work together
to produce strategic plans that address all

426.text:
of that for the next five years but, crucially,
some two-year operating plans: a bit of a

432.text:
novelty for all of us. These two-year operating
plans will make very concrete, what are the

438.text:
steps we are going to do in '14/'15 and '15/'16
to make it real in that short timeframe that

443.text:
we have? They need to be deeply practical
plans, and they need to show in some detail

448.text:
how the various parties to that, wherever
they sit in the local health economy, are

452.text:
going to contribute to it.
One of the things we can do to help with that

456.text:
process is to give some clarity about funding
for individual organisations for that two-year

462.text:
period, because you frankly cannot do two-year
operating plans without clarity of resource.

467.text:
One of the benefits of the '15/'16 spending
review being there already -- and we know

471.text:
already about '14/'15 -- is that we will know
by the time we get deeply into that planning

476.text:
process how much money we have, and we can
make allocations, subject to the Board agreeing

481.text:
that when we come to make the formal decisions,
on a two-year basis, to give people the clarity

486.text:
to plan by.
We are going to put in place a programme of

489.text:
support to commissioners to do this planning,
because it is very clear that this goes beyond

494.text:
what most health organisations have been able
to do in the past. We will all be aware from

498.text:
the authorisation process that the one set
of criteria that was most frequently a challenge

504.text:
for CCGs has been the planning set of challenges
and, therefore, putting an additional complexity

511.text:
and length, as it were, and challenge into
the planning process, we need to put some

516.text:
support in place to do that.
As

526.text:
you would expect, we are doing this in partnership
with the Commissioning Assembly, which of

531.text:
course is our link between NHS England and
the CCGs, to make these things happen in a

536.text:
joined-up fashion, and we have started that
dialogue already, with Ros's support and help.

541.text:
We are also in discussion right now with the
Local Government Association and with a variety

546.text:
of arm's-length Bodies, the national partners
that we have -- whether that be the Trust

551.text:
Development Authority, whether it be Monitor
-- to see how we can make this a truly integrated

555.text:
piece of planning. If we do it on a pure commissioning
basis, you cannot answer half of those questions

560.text:
that I posed at the beginning. It is really,
really important that we have it joined up,

564.text:
and I think there are some good signs at the
moment from the early conversations that David

568.text:
has had with anyone else who is called David
in the country, and the follow-up conversations

574.text:
that we are having with people who are not
called David, just how we might bring all

578.text:
of that process together into an integrated
thing. It is the only way we will make it

584.text:
stick.
There is one additional complication, which

588.text:
is put into paragraph 10, in that, at the
same time as delivering all of that, we will

592.text:
have to make some very substantial savings
in our admin costs, coming on top of the reductions

597.text:
of 30% to 50% that we have already absorbed
in putting this organisation together, and

602.text:
where we are already trying to make sure that
we have that resource in the right place,

605.text:
in the right measure, and able to tackle the
challenge.

608.text:
If you take those two things together, two-year
planning with an enormous ask in '15/'16,

614.text:
and the need to think about what we do with
our admin structures, it is a massive test

618.text:
for a commissioning system that, as David
has already said, has only been in existence

622.text:
for a matter of weeks. We do not have very
long to put these plans together, because

626.text:
we need to start implementing them soon. I
do think that if we tackle this with a real

630.text:
passion, determination and support for each
other, it will give a real impetus to the

637.text:
kind of transformation that we have talked
about in the Call to Action. It will end up

641.text:
being a positive thing, albeit a challenging
thing.

644.text:
That is what I wanted to say by way of introduction.
I would be keen to get any thoughts and help

663.text:
that people around the table can bring to
bear.

667.text:
>> Thanks to the Paul for that very clear
setting out of the enormity of the challenge,

680.text:
which I fully accept. However, I would want
to pay tribute, in a sense, to the recognition

688.text:
that this gives to the importance of social
care in the system, and putting money where

693.text:
your mouth is, is a very important signal,
and I welcome greatly the stretch in social

700.text:
care that we all need, as I say.
The impact of cuts in local government is

715.text:
not evenly spread, and there is a risk, in
a sense. It is not a straightforward replacement

724.text:
for cuts; that is obviously not what is intended,
but there will be places that are definitely

729.text:
having more of an impact than others, and
how our distribution mechanism will assist

737.text:
or, in fact, potentially not recognise that,
I am interested in you thoughts on that.

741.text:
>> There is a precedent question, which comes
back to how we are going to do all of this

746.text:
stuff, which is, who gets to decide the distribution
of this? That is one of the questions that

751.text:
we are currently working through. It will
be no surprise to you, I guess, to recognise

that we think it would be a good idea if we
did that particular exercise. That is not

760.text:
the case with the current social care transfer
that we are required to make, but I do think

765.text:
it would be important for us to do that as
part of the allocation discussion, more broadly,

769.text:
because we need to make sure the total funds
get to the right places in the right measure,

773.text:
and we can only do that if we bring together
the various strands.

776.text:
That is my aspiration, Moira. I think it is
really quite important that that is the way

782.text:
it gets transacted. As we speak, I would not
say that is in the bag yet.

>> Paul raised the point that I think is critical,
and I think we as a Board must wait to see

799.text:
where it comes back. However, I am a simple
soul, and accountability has to follow, whether

807.text:
you are responsible for deciding on where
the money is spent and how it is spent, and

812.text:
the outcomes from it. I will be very keen
to make sure that we can see that absolutely

817.text:
direct line of accountability to spend on
outcomes, and if we are not having that as

825.text:
a Board of NHS England, then I struggle to
see how we can then be accountable for the

831.text:
spend. That is a point that you would expect
me to make.

835.text:
>> I think in principle putting the money
behind driving outcomes based in the community

846.text:
is our direction of travel and has to be a
really, really good thing to do. I like that,

852.text:
and if accepting the enormity of it drives
us in the direction we need to do, we need

857.text:
to understand the implications of that. We
need to start acting now; this is not something

862.text:
we start in 2015 or '16. It is going to afford
some real change very quickly.

868.text:
I am almost more worried about the admin bit,
because it is taking more capacity out of

872.text:
the system. It is taking the capacity to take
the capacity out of the system, the brainpower

877.text:
of the Exec in particular, at a time when
we are trying to not only establish where

884.text:
we are, but accelerate it. This is accelerating
the changes we need to do, and I would love

891.text:
to know what risk assessment -- dare I use
the words -- has been put in place, and just

898.text:
to think that through. Directionally, I love
it; I think it is great. It is a really good

902.text:
thing. It will empower Health and Wellbeing
Boards, it will get people playing nicely

906.text:
together across the country. If we do it at
the same time as getting rid of all the people

912.text:
who can actually deliver it, it probably will
not be quite so good.

916.text:
>> I think that is a really good point, and
I think we should ask for transparency from

923.text:
the department about what the risk assessment
was on the admin cost, so we can look at it

927.text:
and test it ourselves to see how that is,
as well as the conclusions they made about

934.text:
the £3.8 billion. Just to reinforce the point
that Paul makes, this £2 billion is on top

944.text:
of the £4 billion we already have to save.
You cannot focus on the £2 billion alone;

950.text:
you have to do the whole thing. In some of
the conversations I have heard, people have

957.text:
missed that point, which I think is a really
important points, because it is not that we

960.text:
have £2 billion sitting around somewhere
doing nothing, it is tied up in services.

966.text:
The way in which we tackle that is going to
be really important. That is the first thing,

969.text:
just to reinforce how big this is.
The second thing is, I am slightly worried

974.text:
that what will happen is we will get involved
in a long and detailed conversation about

980.text:
the technical ways the money flows in the
system, when actually, the real issue is how

985.text:
we redesign the services. In any planning
system that we have, we need to make sure

992.text:
that that is forefront in everybody's minds,
how we are going to redesign the system. We

999.text:
have to do the technical things, that is absolutely
right, but I just think I can see exactly

1003.text:
where people will go in all that. I think
there needs to be a real transparency, openness

1009.text:
and honesty with the public about what this
means practically. That is why, in a sense,

1016.text:
it reinforces the whole issue of the Call
to Action. Had we not done it, we would have

1023.text:
had to have done it now, I think. It seems
that that is really important as far as we

1029.text:
are concerned.
>> I am just going to echo what has been by

1037.text:
David, which is that I go immediately for
the implications for what happens on the ground

1043.text:
in communities. I guess it drives everything
to a point of, how do we in a sense sign of

1052.text:
the process of service redesign around individuals
and communities? If we do not get that right,

1059.text:
we will end up either fighting about who owns
which bit of the budget, or salami-slicing,

1065.text:
neither of which will work. For me, the implications
are about commissioning, actually, and the

1073.text:
way it drives into the system processes for
understanding what people have, what they

1078.text:
do not have, what they need, and how we will
redesign the services to deliver it and how

1083.text:
we involve them in doing that. We are not
starting with a huge amount of technical know-how;

1090.text:
there is some, but it is not something we
have done, so there is a rapid learning curve

1096.text:
as to how we do that and how we get the sign-offs
all the way up the line. I have to say it

1101.text:
would be in error to paint a rosy picture
of understanding between health and social

1107.text:
care throughout the country. What this is
fundamentally about is power, and what this

1112.text:
forces -- whether we like it or not -- is
a transfer of power, which is not something

1116.text:
we have done systemically, effectively, efficiently,
in the past. It is a really serious shift;

1123.text:
it is almost a paradigm shift forced by the
money.

1128.text:
The other point I wanted to make was that
I am very worried about the implications of

1132.text:
the £300 million. While it is really important
we look at the frontline and all that, I am

1138.text:
really keen to know what the implications
of the £300 million are on us almost before

1142.text:
we start doing the other bit, so we have a
clear understanding of what we can do and

1146.text:
what we cannot in the fixed period of time.
>> Quite blatantly, the aim of this money

1153.text:
rightly and properly is to support those people
who do not need to be in hospital to stay

1158.text:
at home and to get people who are in hospital
and are ready to go home, home more quickly.

1163.text:
We know from the work we do out and about
in the country that actually, whilst often

1168.text:
this is a social care issue, it can almost
equally often be a health services issue in

1173.text:
that the right community services are not
in place, the right primary care services

1176.text:
are not in place. I do hope as we move through
that the way that this money can be used and

1182.text:
the way it is looked at on the ground is that
people remember that it is sometimes NHS services

1188.text:
that are needed to support these individuals,
not just social care ones.

>> I just want to report that we have had

1203.text:
Government Association about this. I guess
you might not find that surprising given the

potential investment that local government

1233.text:

local populations, but then to back that up

service changes. The potential game changer

and political leadership in local government

in the past, I think it is fair to say local

just criticise. I am very hopeful from those

1300.text:
a significantly different quality of collaboration.

been made in that discussion. Paul, is there
anything else that you would like to come

1313.text:
back on, on what you have heard from us?
>> I do not think so. I have obviously taken

1317.text:
note of the sentiment of the Board, if I can
put it that way, and will make sure that gets

1321.text:
worked into the programme. I have taken onboard
in particular the admin comments, which clearly

1325.text:
we will pick up.
>> Thanks for that; and actually, frankly,

the capacity issue is I think just quite scary,
hanging over all of us on top of everything
